Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Designing Ebola Interventions for Large Urban Areas through Agent-Based Modeling and Network Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will construct a mathematical model of the spread of the Ebola virus. The model will include parameters based on the characteristics of the pathogen as well as the behavior of people during outbreak situations. The results from this model will help public health officials to design and execute efficient intervention strategies for the current outbreak based on realistic pathogen features and human behaviors and help them prepare for future outbreaks.

Stemming from existing models, the investigators will develop contact networks utilizing explicit agent mobility based on human behaviors. The model will generate two types of networks: a mobility and contact network as well as a disease transmission network. The model will incorporate behaviors based on evolving self-knowledge, e.g. the set of behaviors that people employ once they are aware or suspect they are infected; as well as behaviors that are in response to interventions and messaging, e.g. complying with recommendations for quarantine or not. This modeling effort contrasts with previous work on disease transmission modeling, because the contact networks will be generated by this model based on representative behaviors as opposed to being applied to the model based on theoretical network structures or previous outbreak data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pandemic diseases affecting large segments of the U.S. population are a continuing threat. Highly virulent infectious diseases and vector-borne diseases such as Ebola, Zika, Dengue Fever, Chikungunya and Avian Influenza, have challenged public health officials in recent years to develop preparations, come up with responses, and implement strategies for mitigating potential effects. For example, Ebola’s high mortality rates of 30 to 90% made the 2014-2015 Ebola Outbreak in Africa a matter of deep concern for governments around the world and to the publics they serve. The potential of similar disease outbreaks occurring in other parts of the world and quickly spreading to the U.S. is well recognized.

In this project, we developed a very detailed, city scale, computer simulation model for simulating outbreaks and person-to-person transmission for various diseases, including Ebola. Although computer modeling and simulation applications in public health have a long history, only recently have models become increasingly recognized as valuable aids to decision making. Specifically, we developed computer generated activity profiles for every individual in the population of Chicago (2.9 million agents) and for the multi-county Chicago Metropolitan Area (6 million agents). The activity profiles indicate the activity that every individual in the simulated population is engaged in at each time step and the place where the activity occurs. Agents move from place to place on an hourly basis according to their activity profiles and specified behaviors. We also developed methods for generating and analyzing the large-scale endogenous person co-location networks arising from the simulation of the individual activity profiles (see image). These networks indicate which individuals would most likely have contact, and where and when that contact would occur.

 Understanding how a pandemic could influence the public’s behavior and the demands that would be placed on the healthcare system’s ability to respond are important aspects of the computer modeling effort. Dynamic activity profiles can be generated for the entire population based on the individuals’ endogenous, real-time behaviors in response to events and situations. As part of this project, we developed a compendium of behaviors observed in the Ebola outbreak of 2014-2015. Behaviors included how people reacted to the outbreak and the actions they took in response, including seeking health care at hospitals and clinics. For example, the model can simulate the response of the population to an epidemic in terms of whether people seek care, take their children out of schools, do not show up for work, etc. The responses of the synthetic populations within the model were simulated for periods of up to 10 years on an hourly basis. We believe that this is the first time that dynamic micro-behaviors have been generated at such a fine grain level of detail and at such large scale for the population of a large urban area. This, in turn, allows us to estimate the demands on the healthcare system and anticipate the required resources, including the level of hospital staffing, number of hospital beds, and the amount of personal protective equipment.

 We have concluded from using the model that a large city, such as Chicago, could be poorly prepared to respond to a large-scale outbreak of Ebola given the heath care resources expected to be in place.

 The results of running our detailed urban scale model would be relevant to policy makers in formulating the U.S. response to the current outbreaks and preparedness for future outbreaks of pandemic diseases, including Ebola. Our hope is that the capabilities developed through this project will advance the science of preparedness for the next pandemic disease outbreak.
